overview_of_class:
To introduce students to the ideological origins and contemporary politics of the Black Lives Matter
movement, including the ways it challenges our understandings of American democracy. The course examines Black Lives Matter as a sociological and political phenomenon. Students will engage
substantially with the literature, research and interdisciplinary theories related to social inequalities in the
United States, gaining the ability to analyze the impact that history, political institutions, and social structures
have on contemporary African American social and political life. More specifically, the course will cover a
diverse array of topics that Black Lives Matter brings to the fore, including the substance and tenacity of
American democratic ideals, whether the American Dream exists, the historical development of the carceral state, race and the criminal justice system, the roots of urban crisis, mechanisms of police accountability and oversight, the ideological roots of Black Lives Matter and the ways it compares to the Civil Rights and Black Power movements, the use and legitimacy of emotions in the public sphere, and university campuses as a site of political struggle.

descriptions.value:

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
After taking this course, students should be able to show they can:

  • Analyze the relationship between race and American democracy, including the robustness of
    democratic norms, key ideological concepts such as democratic reciprocity and democratic suffering,
    and the extent to which the American Dream has been accessible to African Americans.

  • Identify the historical, institutional, and ideological roots of the Black Lives Matter movement and
    compare the movement's orientations, goals, and politics to those of its predecessors.

  • Understand and utilize intersectional analysis to examine the ways that gender, race, class, and sexual orientation impact individual, ideological, and institutional experiences of American democracy.

  • Understand the various public policies that have adversely affected Black individuals and
    communities, including the criminal justice system, welfare policies, the war on drugs, and police
    stops.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
The course will be structured as a seminar in which the professor facilitates discussion among students.
Each student will be responsible for introducing a topic and providing questions that will frame subsequent
discussions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The course requirements are as follows: Two reading analyses (15% each); Two analytical essays (20% each); Peer-review exercises (10%); Class contributions (15%)
